verses.text: After Jesus finished speaking all these words to the people who were listening, he entered Capernaum.
verses.comment: Capernaum was a central location for Jesus’ ministry, with numerous miracles and teachings happening there.

verses.text: Now a centurion had a servant who was very dear to him, and this servant was sick and near death.
verses.comment: The centurion, a Roman officer, cares deeply for his servant—reflecting the universality of Christ’s compassion for all people.

verses.text: When the centurion heard about Jesus, he sent some elders of the Jews to him, asking him to come and heal his servant.
verses.comment: The centurion turns to Jewish elders, recognizing the authority Jesus holds in their tradition—a bridge between Gentile and Jew.

verses.text: When they came to Jesus, they begged him earnestly, saying, 'He is worthy for you to do this for him,'
verses.comment: Jewish elders highlight the centurion’s merit, a rare commendation for a Gentile, showing favor to outsiders.

verses.text: 'for he loves our nation, and he built us our synagogue.'
verses.comment: The centurion not only cares for a servant but also supports the Jewish faith—service to God’s people is honored.

verses.text: Jesus went with them. When he was not far from the house, the centurion sent friends to him, saying, 'Lord, do not trouble yourself, for I am not worthy to have you come under my roof.'
verses.comment: The centurion’s humility prefigures the attitude of repentance and veneration before Christ; his words echo phrases used in Christian worship.

verses.text: 'That is why I did not presume to come to you. But just say the word, and my servant will be healed.'
verses.comment: Faith in Jesus’ authority over sickness; the recognition of the efficacy of Christ's word alone points to his divine power.

verses.text: 'For I also am a man set under authority, with soldiers under me. And I say to one, "Go," and he goes; and to another, "Come," and he comes; and to my servant, "Do this," and he does it.'
verses.comment: Insight into the nature of authority; the centurion sees Jesus’ power as operating with absolute command, a sign of Jesus’ likeness with divine authority.

verses.text: When Jesus heard these things, he marveled at him. Turning to the crowd that was following him, he said, 'I tell you, not even in Israel have I found such great faith.'
verses.comment: A Gentile’s faith exceeds that of Israel; Jesus honors true faith wherever it is found, fulfilling Old Testament promises to bless all nations.

verses.text: And when those who had been sent returned to the house, they found the servant well.
verses.comment: Instant healing confirms Jesus’ supernatural authority; his word accomplishes real change, signifying the power of divine command.

verses.text: Soon afterward, Jesus went to a town called Nain, and his disciples and a large crowd went with him.
verses.comment: Nain was a small village; Jesus’ journey here sets the stage for a dramatic miracle.

verses.text: As he came near the gate of the town, a man who had died was being carried out, the only son of his mother, and she was a widow. A large crowd from the town was with her.
verses.comment: The widow’s loss is total, lacking means and support; prefigures God’s special care for the poor and oppressed (see Ps. 68:5).

verses.text: When the Lord saw her, he had compassion on her and said to her, 'Do not weep.'
verses.comment: Jesus calls himself 'Lord' here—an implicit sign of divinity and authority (see Ps. 110:1).

verses.text: Then he came and touched the bier, and those carrying it stood still. And he said, 'Young man, I say to you, arise!'
verses.comment: Jesus raises the dead by his word alone, just as God did in the prophets; Jesus’ authority here is a sign of his dominion over life and death.

verses.text: The dead man sat up and began to speak, and Jesus gave him back to his mother.
verses.comment: Restoration of life; Jesus’ act is both physical and relational—returning the son restores the widow’s hope.

verses.text: Fear seized them all, and they glorified God, saying, 'A great prophet has risen among us!' and, 'God has visited his people!'
verses.comment: People recognize Jesus as a prophet, yet their words hint at something more—God’s direct action in their midst foreshadows Christ’s divine identity.

verses.text: And this report about him spread through all Judea and the surrounding region.
verses.comment: Jesus’ miracles fuel growing recognition—he fulfills the prophecies that God will visit and redeem his people.

verses.text: The disciples of John reported all these things to him.
verses.comment: John the Baptist’s followers observe Jesus’ works and bring them to their leader, highlighting the transition from John’s ministry to Jesus.

verses.text: Calling two of his disciples, John sent them to the Lord, saying, 'Are you the one who is to come, or should we look for another?'
verses.comment: John asks about Jesus’ Messiahship—significant as confirmation of Jewish longing for the promised deliverer.

verses.text: When the men came to him, they said, 'John the Baptist has sent us to you, asking, "Are you the one who is to come, or should we look for another?"'
verses.comment: The messengers repeat John’s question, seeking clarity about Jesus’ identity and mission.

verses.text: At that hour he healed many people of diseases, afflictions, evil spirits, and he gave sight to many who were blind.
verses.comment: Jesus’ miracles fulfill Isaiah’s prophecy about the signs of the Messiah, confirming his identity as the one sent by God.

verses.text: And he answered them, 'Go and tell John what you have seen and heard: the blind receive sight, the lame walk, lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, and the poor have the good news preached to them.'
verses.comment: Jesus lists messianic works, directly citing prophetic literature—physical healings and preaching the gospel are evidence of God’s Kingdom.

verses.text: And blessed is anyone who does not stumble because of me.'
verses.comment: Jesus hints at the challenge of accepting him; faith in him is the pathway to blessing, recalling Old Testament warnings about a stumbling stone.

verses.text: After John’s messengers left, Jesus began to speak to the crowds about John: 'What did you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken by the wind?'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms John’s resolute character, contrasting him with something weak or unstable—reinforcing John’s prophetic role.

verses.text: 'But what did you go out to see? A man dressed in soft clothes? Those who wear fine clothing and live in luxury are in kings’ palaces.'
verses.comment: John’s rough garment and life reflect his total dedication to God—distinct from worldly luxury often associated with power.

verses.text: 'But what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I tell you, and more than a prophet.'
verses.comment: John is indeed God’s prophet—Jesus calls attention to his unique mission preparing the way for the Messiah.

verses.text: 'This is the one about whom it is written, "Behold, I send my messenger before your face, who will prepare your way before you."'
verses.comment: Jesus confirms John’s fulfillment of prophecy; John’s preparatory role is divinely ordained, building on promises from Malachi and Isaiah.

verses.text: 'I tell you, among those born of women none is greater than John; yet the one who is least in the kingdom of God is greater than he.'
verses.comment: John’s greatness is surpassed by those in Christ’s Kingdom—hinting at the importance of entering the sacramental communion Christ establishes.

verses.text: When all the people, even the tax collectors, heard this, they acknowledged God's way by being baptized with John's baptism.
verses.comment: The people respond in faith and repentance, preparing to receive Jesus; baptism is understood as the entry point into God’s new people.

verses.text: But the Pharisees and experts in the law rejected God's purpose for themselves, since they were not baptized by him.
verses.comment: Some religious leaders refuse John’s baptism, resisting God’s invitation and foreshadowing division within the community of faith.

verses.text: Then the Lord said, 'To what shall I compare the people of this generation? What are they like?'
verses.comment: Jesus addresses the crowd, piercingly identifying their spiritual condition.

verses.text: 'They are like children sitting in the marketplace and calling to one another, "We played the flute for you, and you did not dance; we sang a dirge, and you did not weep."'
verses.comment: Jesus uses a parable to show the generation’s unwillingness to respond to God’s varied calls—whether joyful or mournful.

verses.text: 'For John the Baptist has come eating no bread and drinking no wine, and you say, "He has a demon."'
verses.comment: John’s asceticism was criticized, underscoring the depth of people’s hardness towards authentic spiritual messages.

verses.text: 'The Son of Man has come eating and drinking, and you say, "Look, a glutton and a drunkard, a friend of tax collectors and sinners!"'
verses.comment: "Son of Man" is a messianic title (see Dan. 7:13), and Jesus’ association with sinners demonstrates his inclusive mercy.

verses.text: 'Yet wisdom is justified by all her children.'
verses.comment: The true fruits of faith prove wisdom; Christ’s followers evidence the wisdom of God’s call.

verses.text: One of the Pharisees asked Jesus to eat with him, and he went into the Pharisee's house and took a place at the table.
verses.comment: Jesus enters even skeptical households, showing openness to dialogue and reconciliation.

verses.text: And behold, a woman in the city, who was known as a sinner, when she learned that Jesus was reclining at the table in the Pharisee’s house, brought an alabaster flask of fragrant ointment,
verses.comment: A public sinner approaches Jesus, courageously seeking forgiveness.

verses.text: Standing behind him at his feet, weeping, she began to wet his feet with her tears and wiped them with the hair of her head, kissed his feet, and anointed them with the ointment.
verses.comment: Her acts of humility and devotion show true contrition and reverence; the anointing and physical acts foreshadow sacramental acts of penance and adoration.

verses.text: Now when the Pharisee who had invited him saw this, he said to himself, 'If this man were a prophet, he would know who and what kind of woman is touching him; for she is a sinner.'
verses.comment: Simon doubts Jesus’ prophetic insight, yet Jesus is about to show fuller spiritual vision than Simon expects.

verses.text: And Jesus answered, 'Simon, I have something to say to you.' And Simon replied, 'Say it, Teacher.'
verses.comment: Jesus reads Simon’s thoughts, demonstrating divine insight.

verses.text: 'A certain money lender had two debtors. One owed five hundred denarii, and the other fifty.'
verses.comment: Parable establishes proportional grace and forgiveness.

verses.text: 'When they could not pay, he canceled the debt of both. Now which of them will love him more?'
verses.comment: Larger forgiveness spurs deeper gratitude—Jesus emphasizes the link between mercy received and love shown.

verses.text: Simon answered, 'I suppose the one who had the larger debt canceled.' And Jesus said to him, 'You have judged correctly.'
verses.comment: Simon gets the point; correct judgment is affirmed by Jesus.

verses.text: Turning toward the woman, Jesus said to Simon, 'Do you see this woman? I entered your house, and you gave me no water for my feet, but she has washed my feet with her tears and wiped them with her hair.'
verses.comment: Jesus contrasts Simon’s neglect with the woman's devotion, elevating acts of humble love over mere hospitality.

verses.text: 'You did not give me a kiss, but she, from the time I came in, has not stopped kissing my feet.'
verses.comment: The kiss is a symbol of respect; the woman’s repeated act reflects great love and repentance.

verses.text: 'You did not anoint my head with oil, but she has anointed my feet with fragrant ointment.'
verses.comment: Anointing is a sign of honor; her action further shows Jesus’ royal and divine status.

verses.text: 'Therefore I tell you, her many sins are forgiven—for she loved much. But he who is forgiven little, loves little.'
verses.comment: The link between forgiveness and love is highlighted; deep contrition yields greater reconciliation and devotion.

verses.text: And he said to her, 'Your sins are forgiven.'
verses.comment: Jesus directly pronounces forgiveness—something only God can do—implicitly claiming divine authority.

verses.text: Then those who were at the table with him began to say among themselves, 'Who is this, who even forgives sins?'
verses.comment: The crowd recognizes that forgiving sins is a divine prerogative, revealing Jesus’ unique identity as Son of God.

verses.text: And he said to the woman, 'Your faith has saved you; go in peace.'
verses.comment: Jesus links faith, forgiveness, and peace—a foreshadowing of the salvific experience of reconciliation offered to all who seek him through faith and repentance.
